Introduction
The purpose of this document is to detail the process for ensuring safer staffing across nursing within Mid and South Essex Foundation Trust (MSE).

MSE is committed to ensuring that all non-medical clinicians both registered and unregistered, match the acuity and dependency needs of patients within clinical ward areas across the Trust. This includes an appropriate level and skill mix of nursing staff to provide safe and effective care.

There is a requirement for all Trusts with in-patient beds to publish their staff rates (actual v planed) in hours, taking into consideration day and night shifts and both registered and unregistered staff. This information appears on the NHS choices website. Patients and the public are now able to see how hospitals are performing and this indictor on the NHS choice website.

For inpatient areas, the ward establishment may include allied health professionals and other support staff (such as Pharmacists, Advanced Clinical Practitioners/ Clinical Nurse Specialists), depending on the model of care being delivered. However it is important to ensure that other support staff that are included as part of the core establishment are both rostered on the ward team's roster and are ward based. Staff who provide care on defined number of sessions basis would not be considered as part of the ward core establishment.

Each inpatient ward is also required to publically display staff numbers on a shift by shift basis. The ward staffing Today poster is required to be updated at the start of each shift by the nurse in charge-detailing the number of expected staff on each shift together with the actual number of staff on each shift. Any shortfalls in numbers will be managed as per the identified process in section three of this policy.
Real time management of staffing levels to mitigate risk

The MSE definition of ‘safe' levels is the agreed clinical establishment for registered and unregistered staff within the establishment for each area. This is reinforced by agreed ratios of registered versus unregistered staff.

In the event of shortfalls of staff or unexpected increases in patient acuity and dependency requirements, the agreed staffing levels are reviewed and RAG rated (Red/Amber/Green) with escalation actions specified at each level.
Green Shifts are determined to be safe levels and would not require escalation as these constitute the levels expected through the agreed establishment.

Amber Shifts are determined to be at a minimum safe level. The matron will be alerted, but no further escalation will be required. Staff will prioritise their work and adjust their workload through the shift accordingly, with a continual review of any changes to the acuity and dependence.

Red Shifts are determined to be at an unsafe level with inadequate staffing to meet the patient needs. The Matron and ADoN's will be alerted. Mitigating actions will be taken, and documented, which may include;
The movement of staff- including temporary staff, allied health professionals and the wider clinical team from another ward or community care team to cover duties where appropriate.
Logging of the incidents on Datix.
Utilisation of supernumerary staff within the numbers where appropriate.
By mutual agreement cancellation of leave, administration shifts, non- essential training, time owing and management days.
In exceptional circumstances activity could be reduced through reduction in the number of beds, or caseloads.

Completion of these actions may address / reduce the risk and reduce the shift to an amber rating. Red shifts are escalated in daily staffing meetings with the Matrons and ADoN/DDoN's. Actions are monitored for effectiveness.
In extreme circumstances we may move into Black which is when all mitigation is taken but we still remain at high risk with 60% of wards at less than planned staffing levels. Please see table below.

data.text: Daily process to manage staffing
A flow chart of the following process is included within appendix

Safe  staffing  levels  are  managed  on  a  daily  basis  by  the  Team  Leader/Ward Manager. Consideration is given to bed capacity and operational activity within the Trust which may impact on safe staffing.

Amber and Red teams are escalated to the Matron. Actions are agreed to ensure that all areas are made safe, this may mean that a green rated ward/team become amber, due to the movement of staff to a ward/team that initially triggered, usually as a consequence of short term sickness or other unplanned leave.
Red teams will be escalated by the Matron to the ADoN, or Director of Nursing, Deputy Director of Nursing through staffing meetings and the Datix system when incident logged.

Temporary staffing requests, absence and acuity and dependency levels are reviewed with team leaders/ ward managers/ matrons to provide escalation reporting and to action and resolve known staffing issues.

The Trust board have ultimate accountability for ensuring that MSE is compliant to providing safe levels of staff. The shift fill and any concerns are raised through meetings held with the Professional Leads/ Divisional Nursing Directors.
Monthly review process to monitor staffing levels
Staffing levels are reviewed at Divisional Monthly Meetings. Inpatient fill rates are reported externally to NHS England and publicly published.
The Trust Executive Committee review published information on ward level staffing and exception reports which are produced in ‘heat map' format.
Quarterly review process to monitor staffing levels
Reports are provided by the Director of Nursing/ Deputy Chief Nurse to the People and organisation development (POD).
Workforce plans are developed and reported through the Workforce committee to plan recruitment priorities, skill mix reviews, training and development and the introduction of new roles.
Six monthly acuity and dependency measurements to inform safe
staffing

Acuity and dependency measurements of inpatients and caseloads takes place on a six monthly basis using National evidence based tools and a professional judgement framework. A map of this process is included within Appendix  After the 3rd review a review team meeting will take place.

The results of the acuity and dependency measurements will be discussed in a face to face meeting between clinical team and the review team. The review team membership will be Multidisciplinary and will include a minimum:
Team manager.
Representative involved in delivering direct care.
Finance representative.
Workforce and staff side.
Service user or carer attending.
Safe staff lead.
A senior clinical lead (8A or above) should chair review.

Before the meeting the review chair will access the self-assessment document (appendix 3). This will provide assurance that the team is cross-checking data using evidence-based guidance and presenting a rounded view of staffing requirements to support professional judgement and decisions about delivering high quality, safe care to patients. The discussion will review all budgeted establishments/ teams to identify any resource variances.

Results are presented via the Director of Nursing to the Trust Board for discussion and approval prior to establishment changes. This report will also be available to commissioners. If any changes take place to establishment levels, e-roster templates will be updated locked and budgets re-set in line with the new financial year.
‘Safe staffing information packs' to support safe staffing levels

Safe staffing information packs are located within each ward, department and available on the intranet, providing guidance upon ‘good rostering' practice, temporary staff booking procedures and a copy of this policy. Staff members should ensure that they are familiar with the location and content of these information packs, and that the policy within it is the most up to date version and contacting their line manager for further guidance if required.
Red flags

Red flags are those occurrences stipulated by NICE (July 2014) which maybe an indicator that the quality of care has declined and patients are being made vulnerable. Should any of these occur, escalation to the service Matron for investigation should follow immediately. It could be necessary to increase staffing levels on the basis of these events. This should be recorded on the Incident Reporting System and the management of the situation must then follow the route as stipulated in section 3 if the area is deemed to be unsafe.
Unplanned omission in providing patient medications.
Delay of more than 30 minutes in providing pain relief.
Patient vital signs not assessed or recorded as outlined in the care plan.

Delay or omission of regular checks on patients to ensure that their fundamental care needs are met as outlined in the care plan. Carrying out these checks is often referred to as 'intentional rounding' and covers aspects of care such as: Pain: asking patients to describe their level of pain level using the local pain assessment tool. Personal needs: such as scheduling patient visits to the toilet or bathroom to avoid risk of falls and providing hydration. Placement: making sure that the items a patient needs are within easy reach. Positioning: making sure that the patient is comfortable and the risk of pressure ulcers is assessed and minimised.
Less than 2 registered nurses present on a ward during any shift.
Extra for Paediatrics:
Delay in providing enteral feeds by more than 30 mins in Paediatric areas.
Observations not assessed or recorded as outlined in the PEWS escalation guidance in Paediatric areas.
Staffing ratios are not meeting RCN guidance or Critical Care ratios in Paediatric or Neonatal areas.
Definitions

table_items.text: This is the term used to describe the number of whole time equivalents funded in an area. This is worked out by detailing the number of staff required on a certain band each shift. Percentage uplift is added to this figure to cover annual leave, study leave and short term sickness. There is a corporate long term sickness and maternity leave reserve that forms part of the overall uplift. The establishment is individual to each ward, department or community team.

Part of the electronic rostering system, safe care is software that allows acuity and dependency scoring based on the Shelford scoring system. This creates a live view of staffing that takes into account the numbers and needs of patients.

Is the review of staffing levels of both registered and un-registered staff benchmarked against acuity and dependency scoring. This information is triangulated with professional judgement and nurse sensitive indicators

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Role of the Chief Nurse
Ensuring that ward establishments are safe, appropriate and in line with national benchmarks.
To assure the Trust Board as to the safety of staffing levels.
Ensuring senior nurses/matrons adhere to this policy.
Providing professional and strategic leadership to all nursing staff.
Role of the Deputy Chief Nurse/ Associate Director of Nursing
Supporting and deputising for the chief nurse and undertaking a delegated responsibility for:
Ensuring that the ward establishments are safe, appropriate and in line with national benchmarks.
Ensuring that senior nurses/matrons adhere to this policy.
Providing professional and strategic leadership to all nursing staff.
Ensuring adequate temporary staffing provision through NHSP, Bank and nursing agencies.
Reviewing staffing incident reports and producing appropriate action plans.
Role of the Matron
Supporting the Director of nursing in ensuring that ward team establishments are safe, appropriate and in line with national benchmarks.
Informing the director of nursing and appropriate associate director and divisional nurse when establishments do not meet the needs of the service and need to be reviewed.
Agree daily escalation position.
Ensuring that ward sisters/department heads, adhere to Trust polices and use of safe care tool to ensure achievement of required ward establishments and safe daily staffing levels.
Ensuring that ward sisters, department heads adhere to the Trust e-roster policy when producing rosters.
Ensuring that appropriate measures are taken so that all wards and departments are risk assessed and staffed appropriately.
Reviewing and approving the monthly rosters.
Escalating to the deputy Director of nursing when staffing levels are predicted to be unsafe as per Appendix
Site Manager
Holding the staffing bleep when required as part of the staffing bleep holder rota.
Ensuring that appropriate measures are taken so that all wards and departments are risk assessed and staffed appropriately.
Escalating any staffing safety concerns to the clinical matron responsible for that area and/or duty manager.
Adhering to the trust roster policy and updating the safe care system in real time.
Ward Sister/Charge Nurse
Ensuring that ward rosters are written according to the trusts e-roster policy.
Ensuring that recruitment and selection is carried out in a timely way and according to the Trusts recruitment and selection policy and the trusts recruitment guidelines.
Ensuring that shifts are placed on Bank in a timely way and according to the agreed processes.
Ensuring that trained staff are familiar with the safe care element of the electronic health roster.
Informing the matron when establishments do not meet the needs of the service and need to be reviewed.
Adhering to Trust policies.
Role of nurse in charge of the shift
Ensuring that the census data is entered three times a day.
Escalating any staffing concerns to the staffing bleep holder.
Raising red flags to any lapses in patient care.
Adhering to trust policies.
Daily process to managing staff
Safe staffing levels are managed on a daily basis by the ward sister and Matrons. Staffing tactical meetings will be put in place if required due to risks to staffing levels.
Safer care application is to be accessed during this meeting to:
Ensure three times a day census reports are completed. Highlight and action those areas that have not completed census report.
Highlight areas that are amber or red Highlight patients that require additional observation as per the enhanced observation policy.
Determine those areas that have initiated red flags.
Engage in discussion to mitigate the risks identified.
Provide professional judgement commentary to ‘at risk' areas.
Determine RAG rating of staffing and update intranet.
Red shifts are to be escalated by the matron to the Divisional Nurse, Deputy Chief Nurse and chief nurse.
Agree Trust escalation status.
Deployment of nursing associates

It is recognised that at times staff from all areas across the organisation will need to move in order to meet patient need and ensure patient safety is maintained in all clinical areas. However, it is important to understand that nursing associates are not registered band 5 nurses and we are expected to consider this when re-deploying them. As with the introduction of any other new role, governing bodies are not prescriptive about how we deploy nursing associates, but we must provide assurance that using them is safe and supports delivery of high-quality care.

The nursing associate requires a period of adjustment and support during their transition to a registered practitioner as do newly qualified band 5 nurses. Although we try to avoid this, at times decisions have to be made which may result in a nursing associate being moved to help another area. Should the nursing associate need to be redeployed, this guidance should be considered:

The role of the Nursing Associate is in its infancy and we need to give it time to become embedded. The role of the nursing associate is a new one and only those areas that have supported a TNA during their training programme will be aware of the role and its capabilities. At no point should a nursing associate be expected to move to an area which has limited awareness of the role, and work as a nursing associate or to substitute a Band 5 nurse. In this situation a nursing associate would be expected to work under the supervision of a trained nurse and not take a caseload of patients.
Should a Nursing Associate be redeployed to another clinical area that they are unfamiliar with they should not undertake any practice or procedure that they are not competent to do so.

As part of the daily staffing meetings, staffing levels and skill mix are reviewed continually and it is key that we continue to use the professional judgement of our clinical leaders and staff when making decisions on redeployment of any role.
Monitoring compliance with and the effectiveness of the policy
Standards/Key Performance comprises:
E-roster reports.
Divisional budgetary reviews.
Nurse sensitive indicators.
Staffing incident report.
Staff survey result.
Patient survey results.
Reduction in incidents/complaints.
Training requirements

The purpose of Healthroster training is to ensure all staff with nominated access to the system are using it in unified way that supports trust policies and procedures. Training is delivered via training videos, and followed up with face to face sessions or online meetings where additional training needs are identified or requested.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Senior nursing teams with sign off from the Directors of Nursing and Chief Nurse, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Senior Nurses of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Preliminary equality analysis
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
